messageBody:
> -----Original Message-----

[...]
> > 2) What are the tools you use for creation of unit tests, if any?
>
> One of the main reasons I'm loyal to JPad pro is the fact that it
> will let me create as many class templates as needed (I have well
> over a dozen for Java alone), including the boilerplate for test
> cases (if anyone here uses JPad Pro and wants them, let me know).

Cool. TextEdit has a similar template feature (for any kind of file, I
think). Have you done any comparison there?

> Other tools don't support this very well and I don't understand why-
> I'm mainly thinking about Eclipse and IntelliJ, but often when I say
> these IDEs don't do something, I get corrected ;).

Eclipse has nice support for right-clicking on a file to create a JUnit
TestCase or suite. And the built-in test runner was provided by Erich
Gamma, who works for OTI (the IBM subsidiary behind Eclipse). But
that's not the same as what you're talking about. Eclipse has built-in
support for customizable and extensible templates for lots of stuff like
Javadoc elements, flow control and iteration constructs, etc. but not
file-level templates. Until you pointed it out, I didn't realize it,
but it seems like you are correct. I mean, Eclipse is extremely
extensible, so someone could implement this, but I don't see anything
like it in the default platform or Java Dev Tools. Closest thing would
be to implement a new wizard for each type of template.

NetBeans has a similar "create JUnit TestCase" feature, which is even
quicker to use than Eclipse's. But NetBeans', by default, imports a
NetBeans package into your TestCase and makes your TestCase extend their
own NBTestCase. But that behavior can be fixed by modifying the
TestCase preferences.

> One think I don't like about the way Junit does test suites, aside
> from the effort of remembering to add a test to a suite, is that it
> drives the dependencies downward. AllTests at the top of the tree
> has to know about all the tests or testsuites below it.

Yes, this is a pain. I prefer to use Ant's <batch/> JUnit test runner,
which can make nice ASCII/XML/HTML (via <junitreport/> task) reports and
has a test collector that picks up test cases automatically and allows
filtering of test cases by name.

> > 3) Do you prefer using tools for unit tests creation?
>
> Only for blowing out the test boilerplate.

I agree. Minimal and preferably customizable tes case generation is
most helpful.

Scott Stirling
